title: Welcome!
text: Hi! My name is Julia Martin and I am a first year ScM student in Biostatistics at Johns Hopkins. I’m from California and one of my favorite hobbies is biking. Here is a picture of me biking in Yosemite from the summer!

title: About Me
text: I am a first year Biostatistics ScM student at the Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health. I graduated from UCLA in June 2024 with a Bachelor of Science in Statistics and Data Science and a Minor in Public Health. While studying at UCLA, I was a student researcher at the UCLA Department of Medicine Statistics Core, in which I assisted a senior statistician in data analysis on patterns in childhood trauma using R. My current interests include using EHR data to make predictions about patient outcome and improve medical practice.

title: Example Analysis - Flight Delays at BWI
text:
(Airport 2024)
In this analysis, I explored what factors characterize delayed flights out of BWI airport in 2015. Which airline carriers were most likely to have delayed flights? Were flights more likely to be delayed during certain months? Were there any associations between flight time and length of delay? This analysis intended for air travelers in the U.S., frequent or infrequent, sheds some light on the previous questions using U.S. domestic flight data from 2015. This dataset is from Kaggle (Transportation 2016) and was originally produced by the Department of Transportation’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics. The original dataset has 5.8 million observations, each one a different flight, and 31 columns with information about the flight including date of flight, carrier, flight status, and reason for possible delay, diversion, or cancellation. To narrow down the data analysis, I filtered the data to only include flights departing from BWI so I can focus the analysis on flight status out of BWI airport. There were 86,079 flight observations out of BWI in 2015. The data source also includes two small tables with airport and airline abbreviations used in the dataset.






Note



The original dataset is very large so I did not upload it to the GitHub repository. Instead, I filtered the dataset by flights outgoing from BWI only and uploaded that subset to my GitHub repository for this website (called flights_bwi.csv). I wrote code below showing how I filtered the originaly dataset, but for reproducing this code, please begin by readings in flights_bwi.csv, not flights.csv.



library(dplyr) 
library(stringr)
library(knitr)
library(ggplot2)
library(kableExtra)


flights <- read.csv("flights.csv") # Read in data

flights.bwi <- flights %>% # Filter by only flights originating from Baltimore
  filter(ORIGIN_AIRPORT == "BWI")
write.csv(flights.bwi, "flights_bwi.csv")


flights_bwi <- read.csv("flights_bwi.csv") # Reread in smaller dataset
airports <- read.csv("airports.csv") # Read in airport and airline data
airlines <- read.csv("airlines.csv")


Data Dictionary






IATA_CODE
AIRLINE




UA
United Air Lines Inc.


AA
American Airlines Inc.


US
US Airways Inc.


F9
Frontier Airlines Inc.


B6
JetBlue Airways


OO
Skywest Airlines Inc.


AS
Alaska Airlines Inc.


NK
Spirit Air Lines


WN
Southwest Airlines Co.


DL
Delta Air Lines Inc.


EV
Atlantic Southeast Airlines


HA
Hawaiian Airlines Inc.


MQ
American Eagle Airlines Inc.


VX
Virgin America







Variable
Description




Year
Year of the Flight Trip


Month
Month of the Flight Trip


Day
Day of the Flight Trip


Day_of_Week
Day of week of the Flight Trip


Airline
Airline Identifier (See table in right margin for airline codes)


Flight_Number
Flight Identifier


Tail_Number
Aircraft Identifier


Origin_Airport
Starting Airport (All BWI for this analysis)


Destination_Airport
Destination Airport (See list of airport codes here (NationsOnline, n.d.))


Scheduled_Departure
Planned Departure Time


Departure_Time
Wheel_Off - Taxi_Out


Departure_Delay
Total Delay on Departure


Taxi_Out
The time duration elapsed between departure from the origin airport gate and wheels off


Wheels_Off
The time point that the aircraft’s wheels leave the ground


Scheduled_Time
Planned time amount needed for the flight trip


Elapsed_Time
Air_Time +Taxi_In + Taxi_Out


Air_Time
The time duration between wheels_off and wheels_on time


Distance
Distance between two airports


Wheels_On
The time point that the aircraft’s wheels touch on the ground


Taxi_In
The time duration elapsed between wheels-on and gate arrival at the destination airport


Scheduled_Arrival
Planned arrival time


Arrival_Time
Wheels_On + Taxi_In


Arrival_Delay
Arrival_Time - Scheduled_Arrival


Diverted
Aircraft landed on airport that out of schedule


Cancelled
Flight Cancelled (1 = cancelled)


Cancellation_Reason
Reason for Cancellation of flight: A - Airline/Carrier; B - Weather; C - National Air System; D - Security


Air_System_Delay
Delay caused by air system


Security_Delay
Delay caused by security


Airline_Delay
Delay caused by the airline


Late_Aircraft_Delay
Delay caused by aircraft


Weather_Delay
Delay caused by weather



Which airline carriers are most likely to have delayed flights? Are flights more likely to be delayed during certain months? Are there certain airport destinations that have a higher rate of delays from Baltimore compared to other destinations?


Analysis

flights_bwi %>% 
  filter(DEPARTURE_DELAY > 0) %>% 
  nrow / nrow(flights_bwi)

[1] 0.4863672

delayed <- flights_bwi %>% 
  filter(DEPARTURE_DELAY > 15) 
nrow(delayed) / nrow(flights_bwi)

[1] 0.2330534


48.6% of flights out of BWI in 2015 were delayed. However, the Federal Aviation Administration defines a delay as a flight that leaves 15 or more minutes late. (Administration, n.d.) Using this definition, 23.3% of flights out of BWI were delayed.

delay_by_airline <- flights_bwi %>% 
  mutate(delay_status = ifelse(DEPARTURE_DELAY > 15, 1, 0)) %>% 
  filter(!is.na(delay_status)) 

summarized_delays <- delay_by_airline %>% 
  group_by(AIRLINE) %>% 
  summarize(num_delayed_flights = sum(delay_status,na.rm = T), total_flights = n(), proportion_of_flights_delayed = sum(delay_status, na.rm = T)/n()) %>% 
  arrange(-proportion_of_flights_delayed)
summarized_delays

# A tibble: 11 × 4
   AIRLINE num_delayed_flights total_flights proportion_of_flights_delayed
   <chr>                 <dbl>         <int>                         <dbl>
 1 OO                        1             1                         1    
 2 NK                      786          2776                         0.283
 3 WN                    16404         62887                         0.261
 4 MQ                      251          1052                         0.239
 5 UA                      620          2966                         0.209
 6 EV                       56           341                         0.164
 7 AA                      624          4075                         0.153
 8 AS                       60           414                         0.145
 9 B6                      220          1734                         0.127
10 DL                      809          6484                         0.125
11 US                      230          1870                         0.123


This table sorts the airlines by proportion of flights delayed from most to least.






Note



Skywest only has one observation in this dataset and it was a delay, so I will remove it from analysis on which airlines have the highest rate of delay since it skews the results.



delay_by_airline <- delay_by_airline %>% 
  filter(AIRLINE != "OO") %>% 
  mutate(AIRLINE = reorder(AIRLINE, -delay_status))

ggplot(delay_by_airline, aes(fill = as.factor(delay_status), y = length(delay_status), x = AIRLINE)) + 
  geom_bar(position="fill", stat="identity") + ggtitle("Proportion of Flights Delayed out of BWI by Airline") + 
  xlab("Airline") + 
  ylab("Proportion of Flights Delayed") + 
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Delay Status")) + 
scale_fill_manual(labels = c("No", "Yes"), values = c("green4", "orange2")) + 
  theme(title = element_text(family = "Optima"), legend.text = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.x = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.y = element_text(family = "Optima")) + 
  labs(subtitle = str_wrap("Spirit Airlines and Southwest Airlines have the highest proportion of delayed flights while US Airways has the lowest"), caption = "Figure 1: Airlines ranked by delay status")









summarized_delays %>% 
  filter(AIRLINE != "OO") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(AIRLINE,-total_flights),y = total_flights)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "green4") + ylab("Total Number of Flights") + xlab("Airline") + ggtitle("Frequency of Flights out of BWI by Airline") +
  theme(title = element_text(family = "Optima"), legend.text = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.x = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.y = element_text(family = "Optima")) + labs(subtitle = "Southwest operated far more flights out of BWI in 2015 compared to other airlines", caption = "Figure 2: Airlines ranked by number of total flights")








Comparing Figure 1 and Figure 2, we see that Southwest Airlines has both a high proportion of delayed flights but also a large number of flights operating out of BWI. The information from Figure 2 may provide insight to better understand Figure 1. For example, is possible that since BWI is a Southwest hub, this influences the destinations it flies to which could have implications on delays that differ from the other airlines.

delay_by_airline %>% 
  group_by(MONTH) %>% 
  mutate(MONTH = as.factor(MONTH)) %>% 
  summarize(proportion_delayed = sum(delay_status)/length(MONTH)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = MONTH, y = proportion_delayed, group = 1)) +
  geom_path(linetype = "dashed", color = "green4") +
  geom_point(color = "green4") + 
  ggtitle ("Proportion of Flights out of BWI Delayed by Month") + 
  ylab("Proportion Delayed") + xlab("Month") +
  theme(title = element_text(family = "Optima"), legend.text = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.x = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.y = element_text(family = "Optima")) + labs(subtitle = "June and July saw the highest rates of delays out BWI in 2015", caption = "Figure 3: Delay rates by month")








This line graph shows the trends in delays throughout the year. The highest rate of delay occurred during the summer in June and July (perhaps due to an increase in summer traveling or vacations), while the lowest rates were in April and November. Moderate delay rate occurred from December to March, which was perhaps due to more severe weather events such as snow during the Winter months.






Caution



This dataset does not include any observations on flights out of BWI during October 2015 and there is no documentation about this from the data source.


To further explore that hypothesis, I made a plot showing the proportion of delays each month that were due specifically to weather.

delay_by_airline %>% 
  filter(delay_status == 1) %>% 
  mutate(weather_delay_status = case_when(
    WEATHER_DELAY < 15 ~ 0,
    WEATHER_DELAY >= 15 ~ 1,
    is.na(WEATHER_DELAY) ~ 0
  )) %>% 
  group_by(MONTH) %>% 
  mutate(MONTH = as.factor(MONTH)) %>% 
  summarize(proportion_delayed = sum(weather_delay_status)/length(MONTH)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = MONTH, y = proportion_delayed, group = 1)) +
  geom_path(linetype = "dashed", color = "green4") +
  geom_point(color = "green4") + 
  ggtitle ("Proportion of Delayed Flights due to Weather out of BWI by Month") + 
  ylab("Proportion Delayed") + xlab("Month") +
  theme(title = element_text(family = "Optima"), legend.text = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.x = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.y = element_text(family = "Optima")) + labs(subtitle = "June had the highest proportion of delays due to weather out of any month", caption = "Figure 4: Delay rates due to weather by month")








Interestingly, this graph shows that the month with the highest proportion delays being weather delays is June, so it seems that the delays in the Winter months may be due to a different cause.
Lastly, I explored potential relationship between length or delay and length of outgoing flight. To do so, I split up the delayed flights into 4 categories: a short delay of 15-30 minutes, a short-moderate delay of 30 minutes to 1 hour, a moderate delay of 1 to 2 hours, and a long delay of 2+ hours. Faceting by these categories, I made a histograms to show the distribution of flight time.

suppressWarnings(delay_by_airline %>% 
  filter(delay_status == "1") %>% 
  mutate(delay_category = case_when(
    DEPARTURE_DELAY > 15 & DEPARTURE_DELAY < 30 ~ "Short",
    DEPARTURE_DELAY >= 30 & DEPARTURE_DELAY < 60 ~ "Short/Moderate",
    DEPARTURE_DELAY >= 60 & DEPARTURE_DELAY < 120 ~ "Moderate",
    DEPARTURE_DELAY >= 120 ~ "Long"
  )) %>% 
  mutate(delay_category = factor(delay_category, levels = c("Short", "Short/Moderate", "Moderate", "Long"))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = AIR_TIME, group = delay_category)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y= after_stat(width*density)), fill = "green4", bins = 35) +
  facet_wrap(~delay_category) + xlab("Air Time (Minutes)") + 
  ylab("Density") + 
  ggtitle("Distribution of Flight Time Categorized by Length of Delay") + 
  theme(title = element_text(family = "Optima"), legend.text = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.x = element_text(family = "Optima"), axis.text.y = element_text(family = "Optima"), strip.text.x = element_text(family = "Optima")) + labs(subtitle = str_wrap("Delayed flights with shorter delays had higher density of shorter flight times Short = 15-30 min delay, Short/Moderate = 30 min-1 hour delay,      Moderate = 1-2 hour delay, Long = 2+ hour delay", width = 80), caption = "Figure 5: Distribution of flight time by length of delay"))

Warning: Removed 127 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_bin()`).









This faceted plot shows that the distributions of flight time for the shorter delays are slightly more right skewed compared to the longer delays. This suggests that flights with shorter delays are more likely to be shorter flights. Perhaps a more informative way to explore this trend would be to reverse the conditional probability and look at the distribution of delay time based on flight time. However, making visual aids for this type of analysis is difficult because there are some observations with extremely high delay times that make constructing histograms difficult and/or not very informative. For this reason, splitting up delay times into categories as I did here helps account for that.


Summary
Overall, there are definitely factors that influence delayed flights out of BWI. There are clearly trends in which airlines have more delays than others, with Southwest and Spirit being the airlines with the highest rates of delay out BWI. There is also a temporal relationship, and travelers should be prepared for a higher chance of flight delay in June and July compared to other times of year. There also seems to be an association between length of delay and length of flight, of the flights that were delayed. Among delayed flights, it seems that shorter delays were associated with shorter flights. For future analysis, it would be useful to further investigate why this dataset does not include data on October of 2015. It would also be useful to investigate the other causes of delay besides weather delay that were included in the dataset.


Functions Used
dplyr:
filter()
mutate()
group_by()
summarize()
arrange()
n()
case_when()

ggplot: ggplot()
geom_bar()
geom_path()
geom_point()
geom_histogram()
facet_wrap()
theme()









References

Administration, Federal Aviation. n.d. Types of Delay. https://aspm.faa.gov/aspmhelp/index/Types_of_Delay.html.


Airport, BWI. 2024. Air Service Route Map. https://bwiairport.com/flying-with-us/flights/bwi-route-map/.


NationsOnline. n.d. IATA 3-Letter Codes of Airports. https://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/IATA_Codes/airport_code_list.htm.


Transportation, Department of. 2016. 2015 Flight Delays and Cancellations. https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/usdot/flight-delays?select=flights.csv.
